qas.question: How many members are on the National Council?
How long do members of both houses of the Swiss Parliament serve?
What are both houses of the Swiss Parliament collectively known as when both are in joint session?
What can citizens use to challenge any law passed by Parliament?
What can citizens use to introduce amendments to the federal constitution?

context: The Swiss Parliament consists of two houses: the Council of States which has 46 representatives (two from each canton and one from each half-canton) who are elected under a system determined by each canton, and the National Council, which consists of <a0_0>200<a0_0/> members who are elected under a system of proportional representation, depending on the population of each canton. Members of both houses serve for <a1_0>4 years<a1_0/>. When both houses are in joint session, they are known collectively as the <a2_0>Federal Assembly<a2_0/>. Through <a3_0>referendums<a3_0/>, citizens may challenge any law passed by parliament and through <a4_0>initiatives<a4_0/>, introduce amendments to the federal constitution, thus making Switzerland a direct democracy.
